Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Small-scale transport operators and political action

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project undertakes an anthropological study of the small-scale transport sector as a window to investigating urban democracy in a post-colonial mega-city. Thus, the project explores urban democracy for which a study of transporters provides a unique and valuable vantage point. This proposed project will be the first to follow the narrative of legal and political claims-making of these transport operators, as they interact with governmental institutions in India. Translating 'paper laws' into actionable regulation is critical for all legal systems. This research queries how these paper laws, rules and regulations are framed, contested and finally implemented in actual practice. The project accomplishes this by mapping the every-day co-operation and contestation in framing regulations between the communities of operator unions, transport bureaucrats, courts, lawyers, and civic associations to sustain the city-level operation of the law, within the broader narrative of city politics and constitutional rights language. Significant contributions to sociolegal research and anthropology flow from this project.

This project asks: How does the political action of small-scale transport operators--the auto-rickshaw drivers, cycle-rickshaw pullers, and erstwhile horse carriage drivers all belonging to the urban working poor, affect democratic processes in the postcolonial megacity? This study undertakes a historically informed, ethnographic investigation on the legal and political processes by which these transport operators become political agents . The research explores how the working poor participate in and negotiate urban governance, not always through extra-legal mobilizations and demands, but also by working within the framework of democratic policymaking, formal politics, and rights language. The study materials date to 1911, when Delhi became the capital. In its study of democracy, the project brings center stage the collective and individual claims for inclusion that the urban working poor make through their political action. This research, employing both ethnographic and archival methods, will be conducted in courts and archives in India, colonial archives in the UK, government offices, and the street in Delhi. This study examines the entanglement of two fundamental queries in contemporary times: a) how does a democracy actually function? and b) the nature of urbanization processes in our cities in times of great economic, social, and environmental precarity. More specifically, the study investigates how democratic functioning intersects with the lives of the urban working poor whose work straddles the organized and unorganized sectors of the economy in a non-western context. The project has implications for remedial measures to aid underserved, poor workers in urban environments in the U.S. and abroad.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Delhi has extreme inequality, the population is transient, and sluggish government amenities are inaccessibleto a majority; yet, puzzlingly at the same time, this research shows that the working poor people are vibrantand active democratic actors. This project seriously considers the democratic struggles of the million plus urban poor employed in professions essential to urban life—exemplified by the small transport operators—as they secure stable work and housing, and shows how citizenship acts and livelihood pursuits for the urban working poor reshape public life in the city. In these challenging circumstances, this research answers the query: how do the working poor use democratic processes to secure livelihoods and transition from newcomers to established residents in the city? The operators’ fight to exist and thrive is representative of the urban working poor employed in critical professions across Delhi, about 10 million people.

By offering a fine-brush portrait of these operators’ livelihood struggles and their interactions with the political, bureaucratic and legal fields in which they navigate, this project shows that both the regulatory agenda of the state and the political intelligence of the operators are vastly more flexible than most readers would expect, demonstrating that the state and urban poor can adapt to one another creatively. This project focusses on how the working urban poors’ political and legal activism engages with democratic functioning and government regulation in Delhi, using the very channels that are assumed to be closed; tracking the full range of activism including street strikes and legal, bureaucratic and political petitioning. The co-PI followed the operators into these ‘zones of engagement’ such as bureaucratic offices, law courts, politician bungalows and the streets. Mapping these zones takes anthropologies of democracy and bureaucracy beyond simply studying elections and material documents respectively, into messy everyday politics of street union leaders, brokers and political parties. This project shows how through a study of these ‘zones of engagement’, ethnographically, a nuanced sense of the everyday working of democracy can be developed. Ultimately, the project investigates urban democracy for which a study of transporters provides a unique and valuable vantage point.Transport Democracy brings a nuanced study of the operator’s insurgent fight for livelihood rights andcitizenship to the fore. Studies of urban democracy beyond the Euro-American context have mostly hoveredabove the city: examining urban planning, big infrastructure projects, industrialization, migration, sprawl andrecently environment, health and the incapacities of municipal government. In contrast, this project studiesboth the high and the low: street level interactions, bureaucratic work, court room drama and politicians’ discussions. Ultimately, these varied observations consider the ways in which ‘zones of engagement’—between the working class and the government—influence lawmaking and regulations in the city, beyond simply parliaments and drafting tables, as the stakeholders and particularly the working poor address issues of fairness, equal treatment and justice. The project’s findings connect the ethnography of democracy with that of law, urban politics and labor. With limited employment opportunities, urbanization in the global south invariably leads to the spurt in informal economies as seen in the cities of South Asia, Brazil and South Africa. Across geographies, informal transport fills the gap of inadequate and increasingly expensive public transport. Thus, this project will contribute to policy analysis and remedial measures that make cities more egalitarian, keeping in mind the rights and dignity of the working class participants, in USA and the global south.
